summary: This document is an email chain between Assistant United States Attorney Maurene Comey and defense attorney Laura Menninger regarding discovery issues in the US v. Maxwell case. It discusses the production of thousands of images from Epstein's devices, the de-designation of Highly Confidential materials, and logistical arrangements for the defense to review evidence in Colorado and New York.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is corresponding with the prosecution about discovery deficiencies, specifically regarding access to and review of photographic evidence.

persons.name: Maurene Comey
persons.context: Prosecutor for the Southern District of New York handling the US v. Maxwell case. She is coordinating with the FBI and the defense to facilitate discovery production and evidence review.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney copied on the email correspondence regarding discovery issues in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney copied on the email correspondence regarding discovery issues in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the case US v. Maxwell. The discovery materials, including images from Epstein's residence, are being reviewed by her defense team.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for US v. Maxwell
events.description: The trial for Ghislaine Maxwell was scheduled to begin on November 29, 2021.

events.title: Defense Evidence Review in New York
events.description: Laura Menninger traveled to New York to review evidence in the government's possession, including Highly Confidential materials, during the week of April 13, 2021.

events.title: Discovery Production Coordination
events.description: Prosecutor Maurene Comey informs the defense that a production containing thousands of de-designated images and all images from Epstein's CDs will be ready by the end of the week, and that arrangements are being made to ship evidence to Colorado for review.

keyFacts: The FBI had approximately 40,000 images extracted from CDs seized from Epstein's New York residence, with about 3,400 initially designated as 'Highly Confidential' due to nudity.

A separate FBI review of CART-processed evidence from Epstein's devices identified approximately 33,747 Highly Confidential images and 895 Highly Confidential videos, indicating a much larger volume of sensitive material than initially conveyed.

The defense was granted permission to review certain Highly Confidential evidence (hard drives and boots) at an FBI field office in Colorado, but other items (photographs logged as 1A items) had to remain in New York.

The prosecution defined 'Highly Confidential' material broadly as containing 'nude, partially-nude, or otherwise sexualized images, videos, or other depictions of individuals,' not limited to child pornography.

There were significant technical problems with the discovery production, including corrupt files, unreadable photo formats, missing metadata, and difficulties for the defendant reviewing materials at the detention center.
